text: have you ever spatchcocked of chicken
before do you even know what that means
it's kind of a funny word for a
flattened chicken in order to spatchcock
your chicken all you need to do is cut
out the backbone I'm using a pair of
scissors which i think is probably the
best tool for it just cut down along the
backbone and remove it completely the
great thing about spatchcocking well
there are a couple of great things one
of the things that it does is make it so
that your roast chicken cooks in 30
minutes instead of closer to an hour
which is really great when you're in a
rush I also find that it helps your
chicken cook more evenly and that's
really nice because sometimes the breast
can be overcooked when the legs are just
done and this really helps because
they're spread out and the legs are on
the outside and they'll cook a little
bit more quickly I love it I think it's
a really really great method do you
remove and well you can save this if
you're gonna make stock or you can get
rid of it and then just turn your
chicken over if you're squeamish about
touching chicken you can wear gloves for
all of this if you'd like I'm just gonna
wash my hands afterwards and then
flatten the breasts just a little bit
and then you fold the legs in and out
and that's a spatchcock chicken really
really easy lift it up put it into a
roasting pan I'm using a cast-iron
skillet because I think roasting in
cast-iron skillets is really great to
cook with your chicken / make a little
sauce / vegetable crush up three cloves
of garlic you don't need to peel them
put them into the pan with your chicken
and then I have a pint of cherry
tomatoes just poke each one a little bit
and these are on the stem so I'm
removing them can't really eat the stem
so there's really no point throw the
tomatoes into the pan with your chicken
you can lift the chicken up a little bit
and get some of the tomatoes underneath
drizzle with just a little bit of oil
about a TSP season with some salt and
pepper and then to help with this
sauciness factor as the chicken is
cooking add a half a cup of a dry white
wine like a Sauvignon Blanc and a
quarter cup of water
have your oven preheating to 500 degrees
to make sure it preheats for at least 20
minutes before you put this in and cook
until it's 165 degrees when checked with
an instant-read thermometer in the
thickest part of the thigh about 30
minutes look at that beauty because
you're cooking in a cast-iron skillet
you might want to check about five
minutes before the recipe says it's
going to be done just to make sure that
the tomatoes aren't over caramelizing or
burning on the bottom of the pan and if
they seem like they're getting kind of
dark you can just add a little bit of
water or a little bit of wine to the pan
the fragrance is amazing but to increase
the amazingness factor tear some basil
leaves over the top and you have a
dinner that everybody is going to swoon
over and it only took less than 40
minutes start to finish make it tonight
you guys
you
